description.narrative: Neem Foundation’s Radicalization Monitoring and Response System (RMRS) was established in 2017 with the aim of understanding the push and pull factors that have led many people, youths especially, down the path of radicalization and violent extremism, which have largely been unaddressed at the national, state, community and institutional level. The Radicalization Monitoring and Response Systems (RMRS) project has identified the historic socio-economic factors in the North-East of Nigeria as high unemployment levels, poor social amenities, deprivation and a weak social service system, to which it has created an Early-Warning System to identify, rehabilitate and mitigate radicalization and violent extremism while promoting peace, reconciliation and reintegration in affected communities.

title.narrative: Conduct research and Develop Peace & Reconciliation Frame-work & Action Plan

description.narrative: Completed Peace and Reconciliation Framework and Action Plan, endorsed and accepted by all stakeholders, especially the Borno State government, and Borno Emirate Council

title.narrative: Endorsed copy of Peace & Reconciliation Frame-work & Action Plan

description.narrative: 3,930 out of 4,608 respondents have responded to Peacebuilding and Reconciliation survey tool (questionnaire), representing 85.2% of the total number of respondents for the survey. Administration of the Focus Group Discussions and Key Informant Interviews will commence upon conclusion of administration of the questionnaire Once data collection is concluded, analysis will commence, after which the research report will be developed and validated. The data from this exercise: findings, recommendations and potential challenges will be instrumental in developing the Peace and Reconciliation Framework and Action Plan which will inspire collaboration between government and community stakeholders towards supporting reintegration and rehabilitation in the North-East. The Framework will be instrumental in achieving the following: - No. of community members reporting improved understanding Peace and Reconciliation processes. - Research report on current community reconciliation models in North East Nigeria - FGD results & report on identified factors, structures and practices necessary to achieve effective peace-building and reconciliation within communities - Copy of Peace & Reconciliation Frame-work & Action Plan

comment.narrative: A total of 4,608 respondents are to be reached for the Peacebuilding and Reconciliation survey (questionnaire) across the three states: Borno, Adamawa and Yobe. For each state, data collection was spread across four Local Government Areas, determined by a criteria that measured the following: - Existing peace structures preceding the commencement of the insurgency - Communities affected by the insurgency - Communities where some level of post-insurgency stabilisation has returned to The selected LGAs include: BORNO STATE: Maiduguri, Bama, Damboa, and Dikwa ADAMAWA STATE: Michika, Gombi, Mubi, Demsa YOBE STATE: Damaturu, Potiskum, Gashua, Geidam Therefore, for each state a total of at least 1,536 respondents, dis-aggregated across the four LGAs per state in 384 respondents per location are to be reached. So far, data collection has been concluded in Adamawa and Yobe states, while data collection in Borno state has been conducted in Maiduguri and Damboa LGAs, with the two remaining LGAs to be concluded in October 2019

title.narrative: Community Stakeholder Meetings on Early Warning and Radicalisation Monitoring

description.narrative: Monthly meetings by Early Warning Committees to monitor, discuss, and respond to reported tensions and signs of radicalisation within supported communities

title.narrative: Number of meetings held by Early Warning Committee Members in a year

description.narrative: Early Warning Committee meetings commenced in March of 2019 across the three North-Eastern states of Borno, Adamawa and Yobe where the RMRS project is currently being implemented. So far, 7 out of 14 (representing 50%) proposed Early Warning meetings have been held in 2 of those locations: Borno and Yobe, while 3 have been held in Adamawa. Through the Early Warning Committee and Early Warning System, a total of 48 Early Warning signs have been reported across the 3 states, with a 46% validity rate (in terms of relevance as incidents on our index of radicalisation).
